food quote@The free goblet must not be neglected; nay
column3: Deipnosophists 1.8)@@

column1: food quote@That is the life the gods lead
column2: when you can dine at others' expense with no thought of the reckoning.%(Athenaeus
column3: Deipnosophists 1.8)@@

column3: what is it? Drinking

column1: food quote@While dark wine is most favourable to bodily growth
column2: white wine is thinnest and most diuretic; yellow wine is dry
column3: and better adapted to digesting foods.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@Wines which are more carefully treated with sea water do not cause headache; they loosen the bowels
column3: cause inflations

column1: food quote@Now Aristotle declares that men who have been intoxicated with wine fall down face foremost
column2: whereas they who have drunk barley beer lie outstretched on their backs; for wine makes one top-heavy
column3: but beer stupefies.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@There's no cure for being drunk
column3: so potent as the blow of sudden grief. It drives drunkenness away so forcibly that cabbages seem ridiculous by comparison.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@In wine ... the gods devised the best remedy for mortal men to dissipate care.%(Athenaeus
food quote@Mnesitheus said that the gods had revealed wine to mortals
column2: to be the greatest blessing for those who use it aright
column3: but for those who use it without measure

column1: food quote@Three bowls only do I mix for the temperate - one to health
column3: the second to love and pleasure
column4: the third to sleep. When this is drunk up wise guests go home.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@Too much wine
column3: easily knocks the legs from under the drinkers.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@Man is
column3: much like wine in his nature; young wine
column5: is bound to boil up at first and do violence; but when it has lost its ferment it grows hard
column6: and after passing the crisis of all these conditions I speak of
column7: and having had this top froth skimmed from the surface
column8: it is at last fit to use; it settles down again and always thereafter is pleasant to all.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@There is wine
column2: which has the strength of fire when it enters into men; it swells them as the north or south wind swells the Libyan sea
column3: and brings to light the hidden things in the deep; so wine drives the wits from men in complete upheaval.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@Man is not at all like wine in his nature; for when he has grown old he loses his flavour
column2: whereas the oldest wine is what we strive to get. The one bites
column3: the other makes up merry.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@But wine is the best gift of gods to men
column3: every dance
column5: goes with wine. It drives all sorrows from men's hearts when drunk in due measure
column6: but when taken immoderately it is a bane.%(Athenaeus
column7: Deipnosophists 2.37)@@

column1: food quote@Philochorus says that drinkers not only reveal what they are
column2: but also disclose the secrets of everybody else in their outspokenness. Hence the saying
column3: 'wine is truth also
column4: ' and 'wine revealeth the heart of man.'%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@One may hide all else ... but not these two things - that he is drinking wine
column2: and that he has fallen in love. Both of these betray him through his eyes and through his words
column3: so that the more he denies
column4: the more they make it plain.%(Athenaeus

column1: food quote@A sweet compelling impulse issues from the cups and warms the heart; and hope of love fulfilled speeds through the brain when mingled with the gifts of Dionysus
column2: sending the thoughts of men to topmost heights.%(Athenaeus
column3: Deipnosophists 2.39)@@

column1: food quote@To be full of wine is the solvent of pain.%(Athenaeus
food quote@I have drunk not to the clouding of my reason
column2: but just so much that I can still surely distinguish the syllables with my tongue.%(Athenaeus
column3: Deipnosophists 2.40)@@

column1: food quote@So it turns out that there is reason in wine after all
column2: while some who drink only water are silly fools.%(Athenaeus
column3: Deipnosophists 2.44)@@

column1: food quote@Those who drink tosts too constantly come to have an unnatural condition of the stomach; it is much more apt to go wrong
column2: and often causes corruption in the food taken.%(2.45)@@

column1: guide@A good guide can tell you the route
column2: how to avoid the rocks waiting to smash your ship
column3: the whirlpools like Charybdis!@@

column1: guide@A guide of the wisest sort - who knows the name of every landmark between here and there!@@
guide@A guide who knows the gods who oversee the ships passing by - the local nymphs
column3: who can reach out from their tombs to help you on your way.@@

column1: guide@You want a guide as handsome as Hermes (but just as good looking)!@@
guide@Why
column2: there are men here who trekked with Alexander
column3: former footsoldiers whore call every port - that’s the kind of man to hire!@@

column1: guide@The best guide can regale you enroute with every story of the place - History! Myth! The local wonders
guide@You can hire in this town a guide as well traveled as Herodotus himself! And just as full of stories.@@
guide@I can steer you to find a veritable Polemon of Ilium
column3: a writer who’s given his life to the craft of travel!@@

column1: guide@Why
column2: I can find you a writer of periploi
column3: careful books that detail coastal routes!@@

column1: guide@You need yourself a periegete
column2: 'those men who are accustomed to take strangers about to all those things which are worth going to see
column3: and to show them every separate thing

column1: guide@You can hire a guide who was a priest in that place! You know the Egyptian priests would meticulously record in their sacred books
column3: all sorts of curious information: this man embraced that habit as well!%(Strabo 17.1.129)@@

column1: guide@A good guide can tell you the route
column2: how to avoid the rocks waiting to smash your ship
column3: the whirlpools like Charybdis!@@

column1: myth@Alope@What tales can you tell me of Alope's past?@This town is named for a princess who loved the sea god! She was the daughter of the king of Eleusis: Poseidon the god of the waves fell in love with her
column2: and she bore him a child Hippothoon
column3: named for swift horses - appropriate for that horse-loving god! The horsey little lad was abandoned by his mother
column4: but a mare nursed it until the shepherds found him. Eventually the royal little tyke was brought to the king: alas for his mother
column5: the king - his own grandfather! - recognized who he was and locked up his mother as punishment
column6: starving her to death. As for the boy
column7: Poseidon eventually turned him into a spring: a watery fate for a watery boy!%(Pherekydes BNJ 3 F 147; Hyginus Fabulae 187

column1: myth@Alope@What tales can you tell me of Alope's past?@Alope lies in the territory of Achaea Phthiotis; behind the city looms Mount Othrys
column2: where Kronos and the Titans had their base when the Titans warred against the Olympians. There too were born the great god Poseidon
column3: Hades who rules the underworld
column6: and Hestia. You will sail into legendary territory!

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@Anthedonians are famous for covetousness - keep a sharp eye on your wallet there! The Boiotians say that greed lives in Oropos
column3: stupidity in Haliartus and covetousness in Anthedon!%(Herakleides Criticus

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@This town has its poets! Anthes of Anthedon was the first author of hymns%(Ps-Plutarch
myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@Be sure to order carefully at your restaurants there! The hake fish grows to great size around Anthedon
column2: but its meat is rather spongy
column3: not very pleasant
column6: Deipnosophistae 7.316)

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@Old tombs and old tales await you! Mycenaean remains are to be seen
column2: and the place flourished from a fine fishing and seafaring industry. And the tales of Glaukos have their start here - he was a fisherman
column3: and an excellent diver
column4: but more than mortal: he has become a god of the sea and a powerful prophet. Some say that he visits
column6: every island and every beach
column7: accompanied by sea monsters and making prophecies.%(Pausanias 9.22.6)

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@Anthedon is the home of Glaukos
column2: the prophesying demon of the sea - and I saw it myself
column3: his transformation into a God! I was not bleary-eyed or peering vainly to no purpose when I saw this fearful thing
column5: I am a countryman and of these parts; and I am always about the land here opposite Chalcis
column6: and am used to accompany the grazing cattle from the byre to Messapion's leafless lofty crag. And it was from here that my eye lit upon it. I saw it when I had come to the bend of Euboia
column7: about the headland of Zeus Crenaeus
column8: right by unhappy Lichas' tomb.%(adapted from Aeschylus

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@The town is the home of the sea-god Glaukos! You may have heard of him: Plato tells us 'The nature of the sea-god Glaukos can hardly be made out by those who catch glimpses of him
column2: because the original members of his body are broken off and mutilated and crushed and in every way marred by the waves
column3: and other parts have attached themselves to him
column4: accretions of shells and sea-weed and rocks
column5: so that he is more like any wild creature than what he was by nature.'%(Plato
column6: Republic 611d)

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@By the sea at Anthedon in Boiotia is what is called the Leap of Glaukos. That Glaukos was a fisherman
column3: on eating of the grass
column4: turned into a deity of the sea and ever since has foretold to men the future
column5: is a belief generally accepted; in particular
column6: sea-faring men tell every year many a tale about the soothsaying of Glaukos.%(Pausanias
column7: Description of Greece 9.22.7)

column1: myth@Anthedon@What are the tales of Anthedon?@You would sail into the home of the sea-god Glaukos! 'So Glaucus of Anthedon
column2: the fisher of the Boeotian sea
column3: having tasted Circe's deadly herbs
column4: when he had plucked those plants cropped by his dying fish
column6: there to find a new home: that fisherman
column7: so skillful with his hooks and nets
column8: who ransacked Nereus' hidden depths and swept the surface which is Tethys' realm that spoiler tossed on the waves amid the shoals he once took captive'%(Ausonius

column1: myth@Doris@Tell me of this place
column2: Doris.@This city bears the name of a sea nymph! Doris was the wife of Nereus
column3: god of the sea
column4: and the mother of fifty beautiful Nereids; she is the right goddess for this city
column5: as she rules over the fishing grounds that flourish where fresh rivers meet the salt sea: her name means 'pure gift'
column6: an apt title for a goddess with access to sweet river water! Hesiod sings her tale: 'Doris of the lovely hair
column7: daughter of Okeanos the river that encircles us all; to Nereus she bore
column8: even in the barren sea
column9: daughters whose beauty is outstanding even among the gods'.%(Theogony 240-244)

column1: myth@Doris@Tell me of this place
column2: Doris. @In the name of this city lies the Dorian race - those who think 'Doris' means 'woodland' or 'upland'
column3: appropriate for its mountain slopes! Dorians are the children of Herakles
column4: who drove away the Dryopes from this site to claim it as their own: you may call them 'hunger Dorians'
column5: since they took such rich farmland! The soil is deep
column6: the water abundant
column7: springing from the Kephissos river; three mountain ranges protect her round about. Those Dryopes were brigands
column8: pirates of the dry land: from there they ranged far and wide%.(Skylax 62)

column1: myth@Euboia@What can you tell me of the island?@This island has had many names! Some used to call it 'big' (Makris)
column3: - others Abantis
column4: for the warrior tribes who lived here (Iliad 2.540-541
column5: 'the raging Abantes who held Euboia and Chalcis and Eretria and Histiaia with its fine vineyards

column2: but my wicked uncle Pelias has stolen the throne: I may tell you
column3: if you had many hours
column4: of how I was raised by the wise centaur Chiron
column6: how Athena herself crafted my ship
column7: how Hera the queen of the gods is always on my side
column8: how rumors of a golden fleece (!) have floated about our trip. @But let us be practical
column9: young hero! As you set out on your journey
column10: you know that you have never relied on the contracts among cities for your bravery on the sea or in battle: the people of Iolcus partake in no network
column11: but do recognize the value of networks. You can select your crew
column13: for the friends they bring you!

column1: network@Kerinthos@Does this town partake in network friendships?@A bald man has more use for a comb than does this town for friends abroad!
network@Larissa (Thessaly)@Is this town part of the networks that tie the world together?@Indeed! Both the network of the Samothracians
column2: famous for the mysteries that preserve men on the sea
column3: and the Aitolian league that stretches across the Aegean

column1: network@Narthakion@Do the people of Narthakion cultivate friendships abroad?@Indeed they do! A single inscription names twenty seven cities among their friends: they are welcomed at Athens with her violet crown
column3: Magnesia on the Maeander
column4: the river that rushes to the sea
column5: Achaians in Aigion - this town celebrates its proxenoi!%(IG IX 2.90)

column1: network@Opus@Do the people of Opus have friends abroad
column2: networks that link them across the waves?@Not a one! They embrace independence
column3: and count on other means to connect themselves to other Greeks. Five pillars are lined up in the neighborhood of Thermopylae
column5: where the noble dead are honored.

column1: network@Pagasae@Do the people of this town have network friends abroad?@No! They are as independent as they are ancient: long ago a Mycenaean port
column2: and before that the neighbors of the towns more than ancient
column3: Sesklo and Dimini
column4: where Neolithic men built walls and fine ceramics
column5: traded in goods that came across the sea
column6: and stamped their possessions with signs of ownership.

column1: network@Pelion@Will I find men here who claim formal friendships in other ports?@No
column2: but you will find legends in abundance!

column1: network@Pherae@Is Pherae a place for network connections?@Its travelers are as lonely as lost little chicks when they travel abroad! No welcoming ties are forged in advance: they must chat up every stranger as best they may!
network@Phthia@Do the people of Phthia have friends in foreign ports
column2: or welcome travelers into their own networks?@You may remember the tale of Penelope
column3: who unplucked every night the fabric she wove to fool the suitors who lurked in her halls. Nothing to unpluck in the web of Phthia! They travel without the safety net of friends established in advance.

column1: network@Phylace@The people of Phylace
column2: do they sustain the networks that tie the Greeks together
column3: though separated by miles of sea?@They care less for networks like a barbarian cares for grammar!

column1: network@Skiathos@I have heard of this tiny island
column2: in a fortunate spot! Do they have network friends who recognize this value?@Skiathians care not for friendships abroad - tight friends in a tight space
column3: their eyes are only on their fellow citizens.

column1: network@Tisaia@Do the folk of Olizon care for network ties?@No more than a wolf cares for the feelings of a sheep!
network@ALLOTHERS@What are the network connections of this city?@{Grab network list - net_Ids from settlement_list spreadsheet connects to ids on available_networks spreadsheet}
